We discuss here the relation between the (2−α)2𝛼(2-\alpha)-exponential family of distributions as presented in Prop. 2.3 and the distributions arising from the Tsallis maxent principle [ref]13. We put in perspective the related work in statistical physics  , information geometry  , and the discrete case presented in the machine learning literature [ref]7 [ref]8. We start by noting that our α𝛼\alpha parameter matches the α𝛼\alpha used in prior machine learning literature related to the “α𝛼\alpha-entmax transformation” [ref]7 [ref]8. In the definition of Tsallis entropies (6), our α𝛼\alpha corresponds to the entropic index q𝑞q defined by Tsallis [ref]13.
However, our (2−α)2𝛼(2-\alpha)-exponential families correspond to the q𝑞q-exponential families as defined by Naudts , and to the t𝑡t-exponential families described by Ding and Vishwanathan  (which include the t𝑡t-Student distribution). The family of Amari’s α𝛼\alpha-divergences relates to this q𝑞q as α=2​q−1𝛼2𝑞1\alpha=2q-1 [18, §4.3]. These differences in notation have historical reasons, and they are explained by the different ways in which Tsallis entropies relate to q𝑞q-exponential families.
In fact, the physics literature has defined q𝑞q-exponential distributions in two distinct ways, as we next describe.
